entries.title: Late Night Food Options After 10pm
entries.content: Most Parisian restaurants close by 10pm, but you have options. Look for brasseries (open until midnight or later) in tourist areas like Champs-Élysées or near major train stations. Many kebab shops and pizza places stay open until 2am, especially in areas like Le Marais, Bastille, and around Gare du Nord. For 24-hour options, check out train stations - Gare du Nord and Gare de Lyon have food options. Supermarkets like Carrefour Express are open until midnight in some locations. Avoid tourist trap restaurants on main streets - walk 2-3 blocks away for better prices and quality.
entries.problem_it_solves: Finding food when restaurants are closed late at night
spoken_phrases: Where can I eat after midnight
I need food now it's late
What's open for food right now
alternatives: Order delivery via Uber Eats or Deliveroo (works until 2am)
Hotel room service if staying at a hotel
Fast food chains (McDonald's, Burger King) open until 1am
warnings: Avoid tourist trap restaurants on main streets - prices are 2-3x higher
Some areas like Gare du Nord can feel unsafe late at night - stay alert
Tipping is not required but appreciated (10% if service is good)

entries.title: Avoiding Tourist Traps and Overpriced Places
entries.content: Tourist traps in Paris are concentrated in areas with heavy foot traffic: Champs-Élysées, around the Eiffel Tower, Montmartre near Sacré-Cœur, and the Latin Quarter near Notre-Dame. Key red flags: menus in multiple languages with photos, aggressive touts outside, 'tourist menu' signs, and prices 30-50% higher than nearby streets. The solution: walk 2-3 blocks away from major attractions. In Le Marais, avoid Rue de Rivoli - go to Rue des Rosiers instead. Near the Eiffel Tower, skip the immediate area and walk toward Rue Cler or Invalides. Look for restaurants filled with locals (French conversations, no English menus), lunch 'formule' specials (€12-18 vs dinner €30-50), and places that don't have someone outside trying to get you in.
entries.problem_it_solves: Avoiding overpriced tourist restaurants and finding authentic local experiences
alternatives: Use apps like TheFork or LaFourchette to find well-rated local restaurants
Ask hotel staff for neighborhood recommendations (not tourist areas)
Look for restaurants with 'bistrot' or 'brasserie' in the name (usually more authentic)
Visit local markets and ask vendors for recommendations
warnings: Restaurants with menus in 5+ languages are usually tourist traps
If someone is aggressively trying to get you inside, walk away
Prices on main tourist streets are often 2-3x higher than 2 blocks away
Tourist menus often have lower quality food

entries.title: Feeling Unsafe at Night - What to Do
entries.content: Paris is generally safe, but some areas can feel uncomfortable at night, especially for solo travelers. Areas to be extra cautious: Gare du Nord and Gare de l'Est (especially late at night), certain parts of the 18th and 19th arrondissements, and isolated metro stations after midnight. If you feel unsafe: trust your instincts and leave immediately. Walk toward well-lit, busy areas with people around. Use main streets rather than shortcuts through parks or alleys. If you're lost or need help, look for a police station (marked 'Police' or 'Commissariat'), go into a hotel lobby, or find a busy café or restaurant. Keep emergency numbers handy: 112 (EU emergency), 17 (police), 15 (ambulance). US Embassy: +33 1 43 12 22 22. Stay in well-lit areas, avoid showing expensive items, and keep your phone charged. If using public transport late, sit near the driver or in carriages with other people.
entries.problem_it_solves: Feeling unsafe or uncomfortable at night in an unfamiliar city
spoken_phrases: I need to get somewhere safe
alternatives: Call a taxi or Uber to get to a safe location immediately
Use Google Maps to navigate to nearest police station or hotel
Enter any open business (café, restaurant, hotel) and ask for help
If in metro, get off at next stop and find station staff
warnings: Trust your instincts - if something feels wrong, leave immediately
Don't take shortcuts through parks or alleys at night
Avoid showing expensive items (phones, cameras, jewelry)
Keep your phone charged and have emergency numbers saved
Gare du Nord area can be particularly uncomfortable late at night
